{{Infobox scientist |name = Mildred Adams Fenton |image = Mildred Adams Fenton.jpg |image_size = |caption = Mildred Adams Fenton |birth_date = {{Birth-date|14 November 1899}} |birth_place = |death_date = {{Death-date and age|7 December 1995|14 November 1899}} |death_place = |residence = |citizenship = |nationality = |ethnicity = |field = [[paleontology]]
[[geology]] |work_institutions = [[University of Iowa]] |alma_mater = |doctoral_advisor = |doctoral_students = |known_for = |author_abbrev_bot = M.A.Fenton |author_abbrev_zoo = |influences = |influenced = |prizes = |religion = |footnotes = |signature = }} '''Mildred Adams Fenton''' (1899–1995) trained in [[paleontology]] and [[geology]] at the [[University of Iowa]]. She coauthored dozens of general science books with her husband, [[Carroll Lane Fenton]], including ''Records of Evolution'' (1924), ''Land We Live On'' (1944), and ''Worlds in the Sky'' (1963). ==Early life and education== Mildred Adams was born near [[West Branch, Iowa]]. She graduated from the University of Iowa, where she met her husband Carroll Lane Fenton while they were both undergraduates. They married in 1921. Carroll died in 1969.{{cite web|url=http://www.lib.uiowa.edu/scua/msc/tomsc650/msc602/fenton.htm|title=Papers of Carroll Lane Fenton and Mildred Adams Fenton, 1963-1966.|work=University of Iowa Libraries Collection Guides|publisher=University of Iowa|accessdate=23 September 2010|date=May 2000}} {{-}} {{botanist|M.A.Fenton}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[https://www.flickr.com/photos/smithsonian/3379022984/ Flickr entry (with discussion on birth date)] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Fenton, Mildred}} [[Category:American geologists]] [[Category:American paleontologists]] [[Category:1899 births]] [[Category:1995 deaths]] [[Category:American geographers]] [[Category:American women scientists]] [[Category:Women paleontologists]] [[Category:People from West Branch, Iowa]] [[Category:20th-century American zoologists]] [[Category:20th-century geologists]] [[Category:20th-century women scientists]]

page.title: Names of the Basque Country (in Spanish)

revision.text:
[[File:Euskalerria.jpg|300px|thumbnail|NASA photo, 21st century]] [[File:Euskal Herriko mapa.png|thumb|300px|alt=Euskal Herriko mapa, A. H. Jaillot-ek egina (XVIII. mendea)|French map, 18th century]] In the [[Spanish language|Spanish]] public discourse the territory traditionally inhabited by the [[Basques]] was assigned a variety of names across the centuries. Terms used might have been almost identical, with hardly noticeable difference in content and connotation, or they could have varied enormously, also when consciously used one against another. The names used demonstrate changing perceptions of the area and until today the nomenclature employed could be battleground between partisans of different options.<ref>"In all of Spain, the Basque country, or Euskadi, is without doubt the place, the social space, the political territory and the cultural community that most commands attention in conversations of place and space. It is a space and a place under intense contestation, construction, erasure, deconstruction and sometimes, indeed, destruction. The struggle over Basque geography is both internal and external. It begins with its very nomenclature. Is the historical homeland of the Basque people Euskadi, Euskal Herria, Vasconia, the Vascongadas, Pais Vasco-Navarro, or plain Pais Vasco?", Nathan E. Richardson, ''Constructing Spain: The Re-imagination of Space and Place in Fiction and Film, 1953–2003'', Plymouth 2012, {{ISBN|9781611483963}}, pp. 261-2</ref>
==List of names used==
The below list contains names applied in Spanish cultural realm to the territory traditionally inhabited by the Basques. Terms originating from other languages (first of all [[Basque language|Basque]], though also [[Latin language|Latin]]) are acknowledged if in circulation also in Spanish. The list contains indisputably [[proper names]] (e.g. "Provincias Vascongadas"), names with unclear or varying usage (e.g. "Provincias Exentas" or "provincias exentas") and names which have never acquired the status of a proper name, though they might have been intended to (e.g. "provincias hermanas"). Names differing only in terms of [[orthography]] are grouped under one heading. Non-Spanish names which barely made it to the Spanish cultural discourse (e.g. "Hirurak bat", "Zazpiak Bat", [[:es:Gascuña|"Gascuña"]]) are not listed.
===Cantabria===
A term sometimes used in official and semi-official prints until the mid-19th century, usually referring to the Basque lands without Navarre and specifically [[Álava]], [[Biscay]] and [[Gipuzkoa]]<ref>e.g. in the 1713 document named ''Real Congregación de Naturales y Originarios de las Tres Provincias Vascongadas'', named also the Jurisdiction of Cantabria for fiscal purposes.</ref> or to Álava, Biscay, Gipuzkoa and [[Navarre]].<ref>e.g. in the Real Decreto of 1847, see Juan Carlos Molero, ''Public Spending and Fiscal Federalism in Spain. Period 1984–1998'', [in:] ''Munich Personal RePEc Archive 2008'', pp. 42-3, available [https://mpra.ub.uni-muenchen.de/8098/1/MPRA_paper_8098.pdf here]</ref> The name contained no [[Ethnicity|ethnic]] or cultural flavor related to the Basque realm.{{Clarify|date=January 2018}} It started to get out of circulation when applied to Basque territories in the early 19th century, with increasing usage focused on [[Santander, Spain|Santander]] and the adjacent area; the [[:es:Provincia de Santander (España)|Santander province created in 1833]] was originally to be named Cantabria. In public usage the term was already firmly related to Santander when the Basque nationalist movement emerged in the late 19th century. Today "Cantabria" is official name of the [[Cantabria (province)|autonomous community centered upon Santander]]; also in unofficial circulation the term is used likewise, with application to Álava, Biscay, Gipuzkoa and/or Navarre only in historical discourse.<ref>the name "Cantabria" sounded as a distant echo of the original term into the late 20th century. Writing in the 1970s, Francisco Letamendía distinguished between two parts of Euskadi: the Cantabrian one (i.e. in the Atlantic drainage basin) and the Mediterranean one, compare Ortzi [Francisco Letamendía ], ''Los Vascos. Ayer, hoy y mañana'', Hendaye 1976, p. 9</ref>
===Euskalerría===
also '''Euskal-Erria, Euskal Erria, Euskal-Herria, Euskal Herria, Euskeria''', always capitalized. In Basque literally ''Basque realm''. The term traditionally in use in different Basque spoken dialects, it was first used in writing (in alavese Basque dialect) in the 16th century and enjoyed renaissance with growing number of Basque prints since the 1880s, filtering into Spanish and used usually as [[Macaronic language|macaronic intercalation]]. Originally it could have referred to a territory, a population, a cultural commonality or all these components together. Most commonly it simply denoted a Basque realm, understood as a conglomerate of historical, regional, ethnic, cultural and religious ingredients.<ref>Javier Corcuera Atienza, ''La patria de los vascos: orígenes, ideología y organización del nacionalismo vasco, 1876–1903'', Michigan 2001, {{ISBN|9788430604456}}, p. 382</ref> Originally it was entirely deprived of political flavor; in the late 19th century it was briefly adopted by emerging [[Basque nationalism|Basque nationalists]] (to denote a Basque land),<ref>though never without controversy. Key advocate of “Euskalerria” was Campión, Javier Fernández Sebastián, Juan Francisco Fuentes Aragonés (eds.), ''Diccionario político y social del siglo XX español'', Madrid 2008, {{ISBN|9788420687698}}, p. 868</ref> who later abandoned it for the sake of “Euzkadi”. In the early 20th century “Euskalerria” adopted a conservative political taste (with some tension between “Euskalerria” and “Euzkadi”),<ref>the tension still persists, see the 2008 football incident [http://gara.naiz.eus/paperezkoa/20081114/106483/es/Los-futbolistas-niegan-jugar-bajo-otra-denominacion-que-no-sea-Euskal-Herria here]</ref> entirely lost during Francoism. In the later 20th century the term was re-adopted by the nationalists;<ref>Fernández Sebastián, Fuentes Aragonés 2008, p. 868</ref> since 1979 “Euskal Herria” is one of two official Basque names of the [[Basque Country (autonomous community)|automous community consisting of Biscay, Gipuzkoa and Álava]].<ref>for the official text of the Basque version see [http://www.congreso.es/constitucion/ficheros/estatutos/e_76_eusk.pdf here]</ref> Geographical application was and is (except official use) ambiguous depending on perceived territorial coverage of the Basque realm; it could include [[Labourd]], [[Lower Navarre]] and [[Soule]] or even territories in [[Argentina]] and [[Uruguay]].<ref>Joseba Agirreazkuenaga, ''Euskal Herria en el tiempo'', [in:] ''Euskal Herria'' 50 (2011), p. 73</ref>
===Euzkadi===
also '''Euskadi''', always capitalized. In current Basque ''Basque land'', originally meaning ''Basque-race land''. The term was created as “Euzkadi” by [[Sabino Arana]] in the late 19th century,<ref>first used in writing in 1897</ref> who felt that “Euskalerria”, “Vascongadas”, “Vasconia” or other terms did not properly reflect the idea of separate Basque race identity<ref>Fernández Sebastián, Fuentes Aragonés 2008, p. 867</ref> and the ensuing distinctive character of the territory the Basques inhabited.<ref>Corcuera 2001, pp. 382-3</ref> In the early 20th century the term filtered into Spanish, though used sparsely, usually as macaronic intercalation, and never [[Lexicalization|lexicalized]]; its precedent terms, briefly considered in Basque, "Euzkadia" and "Euskaria" have never entered wider circulation.<ref>compare e.g. one of the first lectures of Basque nationalism, ''Euskaria para los euskaros'' by Pedro Merladet Lazgoitia, written in 1894</ref> From the onset the term was (intentionally) politically charged, as it served nationalist Basque purposes; it was opposed or ignored by those who preferred to confront Basque political ambitions. “Euzkadi” was the official Basque name of [[:es:Estatuto de Autonomía del País Vasco de 1936|autonomous territory created in 1936]];<ref>see the official text, available [http://www.ivap.euskadi.eus/r61-3039/eu/contenidos/informacion/legedia_euskaraz/eu_3818/adjuntos/Testu_Historikoak/EUZKADIREN_BERJABETASUN-ARAUDIA_1936.pdf here]</ref> “Euskadi” (note different spelling) is currently one of two official Basque names of the autonomous community consisting of Álava, Biscay and Gipuzkoa.<ref>for official text of the Basque-language document see [http://www.congreso.es/constitucion/ficheros/estatutos/e_76_eusk.pdf here]</ref> Originally the term was applied to all territories perceived as forming part of the Basque realm and is still used this way by some nationalist groupings. Seldom used in present-day Spanish, usually as official Basque equivalent of “País Vasco”.
===país eúskaro===
also '''Pais Eúskaro'''. In Spanish literally ''Euskera-speaking country''. The term was in circulation in the late 19th and the early 20th century, though used very sporadically and almost exclusively against a cultural and literary background.<ref>compare ''La Epoca'' 12.03.59, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000251112&page=4&search=pa%C3%ADs+e%C3%BAskaro&lang=es here] or ''Revista de archivos, bibliotecas y museos'' 01.02.97, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000018172&page=40&search=pa%C3%ADs+e%C3%BAskaro&lang=es here], or s</ref> The term strongly focused not only on Basque language, but also on the entire cultural and ethnic realm built around it.<ref>Coro Rubio Pobes, ''La identidad vasca en el siglo XIX: discurso y agentes sociales'', Madrid 2003, {{ISBN|9788497421195}}, pp. 41-3</ref> It was used principally by partisans of the Basque identity, usually understood in cultural and linguistic terms (though also in national terms). Geographical application was ambiguous; prevailing usage ignored existing administrative divisions and pointed to area inhabited by people belonging to the Basque cultural realm. In many respects the term was identical to “Euskalerria”, though “país eúskaro” (except having been a [[neologism]]) emphasized language and cultural dimension, while “Euskalerria” maintained balance between linguistic-ethnic threads and historical-religious threads. Today entirely out of use.
===país vasco===
also '''País Vasco, país basco'''. In Spanish literally ''Basque country''. The term was in circulation in writing as early as in the 15th century, though until the 20th century used rather sporadically. Similar in meaning and geographical application to “provincias vascas”, i.e. could have been applied to 3, 4 or 7 units in Spain and France; the difference was that it underlined unity of the area and did not put its internal administrative heterogeneity on the forefront.<ref>Rubio Pobes 2003, pp. 41-3</ref> The difference between “país vasco” and “país vascongado” was that the former put slightly more emphasis on the Basque character, while the latter tended to be more lexicalized. In the 1920s the term overtook “Provincias Vascongadas” in terms of popular press usage.<ref>in the popular Madrid daily ''ABC'' the usage ratio between “País Vasco” and “Provincias Vascongadas” was 1:1.4 in the 1910s (67 vs 94), 1.4:1 in the 1920s (295 vs 211) and 2.8:1 in the 1930s (until July 1, 1936, 635 vs 226), compare http://hemeroteca.abc.es/avanzada.stm</ref> In 1936 adopted (with both words capitalized as “País Vasco”) as official Spanish name of the autonomous Basque area within the Second Spanish Republic,<ref>for the original text, see [https://es.wikisource.org/wiki/Estatuto_de_Autonom%C3%ADa_del_Pa%C3%ADs_Vasco_de_1936 here]</ref> today it remains official name of the autonomous community consisting of Álava, Biscay and Gipuzkoa provinces.<ref>for the official text, see [https://es.wikisource.org/wiki/Estatuto_de_Autonom%C3%ADa_del_Pa%C3%ADs_Vasco_de_1979 here]</ref> In present-day nationalist discourse it could be applied (capitalized or not) to any area deemed part of the proper Basque country.
===país vasco-navarro===
also '''país vasconavarro, País Vasconavarro, país basko-navarro'''. In Spanish literally ''Basque-Navarrese country''. Never appearing as “país navarro-vasco”. The term was in public circulation since the early 19th century but unlike other descriptions using the “vasco-navarro” adjective (“pueblo vasco-navarro”, “ejercito vasco-navarro” etc. ) it was used rather sporadically.<ref>for a sample see e.g. ''La Esperanza'' 01.09.1845, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0001813189&page=1&search=pais+vasconavarro&lang=es here]</ref> Applied to Biscay, Gipuzkoa, Álava and Navarre when intending to underline any sort of commonality (historical, economic, geographical etc., though rather not ethnic) linking the four. Upon growth of the Basque nationalism it got used against the background of differences between Navarre on the one hand and Álava, Biscay and Gipuzkoa on the other, though with various intentions (to stress or to downplay them). Its confusing political usage led to de-emphasizing of political contents. Today generally out of use, except for historical or specific cultural discourse.
===país vascongado===
In Spanish literally ''Basque-speaking country''. The term entered circulation in the second half of the 19th century; it was used rather sporadically until the Civil War. Almost abandoned during [[Francoism]], following [[Spanish transition to democracy]] it is hardly in use.<ref>''ABC'' usage of the term by decade is 2 (1890s), 7 (1900s), 12 (1910s), 10 (1920s), 22 (1930s), 0 (1940s), 6 (1950s), 4 (1960s), 9 (1970s), 2 (1980s), 1 (1990s) and 0 (2000s)</ref> Similar in geographical application to “provincias vascongadas”, i.e. applied to Álava, Biscay and Gipuzkoa. There were two key differences between “país vascongado” and “provincias vascongadas”: 1) the former was not the official name of the [[:es:División territorial de España en 1833|region]] (though at times used in the interchanging mode), and 2) the former underlined unity of the area and did not put its internal administrative heterogeneity on the forefront.<ref>Rubio Pobes 2003, pp.41-3</ref> The difference between “país vascongado” and “país vasco” (in its 19th-century usage) was tiny; the former was more lexicalized, the latter put more emphasis on Basque (historical, cultural, ethnic) character.
===provincias eúskaras===
also '''provincias Eúskaras, Provincias eúskaras'''. In Spanish literally ''Euskara-speaking provinces''. The term entered circulation in the mid-19th century; used sporadically, it disappeared in the very early 20th century. It emphasized Basque character somewhat stronger than “provincias vascas” and far stronger than “provincias vascongadas”, though still fell short of acknowledging Basque ethnicity as key feature of the area in question; at times it even pointed to patchy nature of the territory discussed.<ref>''Madrid Cientifico'' 508/12 (1908), available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0001767196&page=5 here]</ref> Contained no political contents or undertones. The nascent Basque nationalism did not use the name. Geographically applied to Álava, Biscay and Gipuzkoa. Today entirely out of use.
===provincias exentas===
also '''Provincias exentas, Provincias Exentas'''. In Spanish literally ''exempted provinces''. The term entered circulation in the mid-18th century and was gradually getting out of use in the second half of the 19th century; in the early 20th century it was already entirely defunct. The name underlined that among all Spanish provinces, the ones in question were exempted from standard fiscal and conscription obligations. The term was seldom used to denote homogeneous character of the provinces; it did not underline their commonality, but rather the character making each of them distinct from the remaining Spanish provinces. It contained no ethnic ingredient whatsoever, the regional one was present though rather muted.<ref>Rubio Pobes 2003, pp. 37-38</ref> Geographical usage of the term differed; generally it was applied to Álava, Biscay and Gipuzkoa, though sporadically (especially in the early 19th century) it could have denoted also Navarre.<ref>e.g. José Canga Argüelles, ''Diccionario de Hacienda'', vol. 2, Madrid 1834, p. 461-464 claimed that "este nombre llevan las de Navarra, Vizcaya, Álava y Guipúzcoa", compare [https://books.google.de/books?id=C9rHUP4vnRAC&pg=PA461#v=onepage&q&f=false here]</ref> Currently not only out of use but also almost entirely forgotten term.
===provincias forales===
In Spanish literally ''[[Fuero|foral]] provinces''. The term is in circulation since the 19th century,<ref>compare ''La Epoca'' 09.03.1884, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000444066&page=2 here]</ref> though used rather sparsely. The name underlines that provinces in question enjoy some traditional, separate, province-specific (not region-specific) legal establishments, known as fueros. In most cases usage and context imply detailed administrative coverage,<ref>compare ''ABC'' 29.12.16, available [http://hemeroteca.abc.es/nav/Navigate.exe/hemeroteca/madrid/abc/1916/12/29/011.html here]</ref> which is by no means obvious; understanding might differ depending which provincial legal specifics is considered "fueros". In such cases in public discourse usually the term is applied to Álava, Biscay and Gipuzkoa,<ref>''ABC'' 04.09.05, available [http://hemeroteca.abc.es/nav/Navigate.exe/hemeroteca/madrid/cultural/2005/04/09/018.html here]</ref> at times also explicitly.<ref>e.g. as "tres provincias forales", ''ABC'' 12.03.01, available [http://hemeroteca.abc.es/nav/Navigate.exe/hemeroteca/madrid/abc/2001/03/12/042.html here]</ref> Somewhat less frequently the term is applied also to Navarre,<ref>for historic usage see Ramon Ortiz de Zarate, ''Biblioteca Vasco Navarra'', Pamplona 1870, pp. 134-135, for contemporary usage see ''ABC'' 16.02.02, available [http://hemeroteca.abc.es/nav/Navigate.exe/hemeroteca/madrid/abc/2002/02/16/018.html here]</ref> though this usage prevails in historiographic scholarly discourse.<ref>compare Victor Manuel Arbeloa, ''Navarra y los estatutos de autonomía'', Madrid 2015, {{ISBN|9788416549177}}, p. 70</ref> In specific cases - also usually in historiography - "provincias forales" could mean also provinces in [[Aragon]], [[Catalonia]] and elsewhere.<ref>see e.g. Henry Kamen, ''La Espanã de Carlos II'', Madrid 1981, {{ISBN|9788474231427}}, p. 40</ref>
===provincias hermanas===
In Spanish literally ''sister provinces''. The term enjoyed some popularity at the turn of the 19th and 20th century, though still it was used rather sporadically and in specialized rather than popular discourse. It was unique among all terms discussed here, as it was the only one capturing both diversity (referring to different provinces) and commonality (acknowledging their sister character). It strongly underlined unity of the provinces referred to, usually against a cultural, historical, ethnic or national background.<ref>Rubio Pobes 2003, p. 41, for example compare ''ABC'' 27.07.05, available [http://hemeroteca.abc.es/nav/Navigate.exe/hemeroteca/madrid/abc/1905/07/27/011.html here]</ref> Very much like “provincias vascongadas” and even “provincias eúskaras”, the term was not necessarily employed by partisans of the commonality discussed (in ethnic or national sense), and could have been employed in quite informal mode.<ref>''ABC'' 08.06.99, available [http://hemeroteca.abc.es/nav/Navigate.exe/hemeroteca/madrid/abc/1909/06/08/006.html here]</ref> Geographically the term was applied usually towards Álava, Biscay and Gipuzkoa. "Provincias hermanas" could have been also applied to any chosen Spanish provinces deemed similar<ref>e.g. the provinces of Huesca and Teruel, compare ''ABC'' 16.09.08, available [http://hemeroteca.abc.es/nav/Navigate.exe/hemeroteca/madrid/abc/1908/09/16/008.html here]</ref> or even generally, to all Spanish provinces.<ref>compare ''ABC'' 14.04.04, available [http://hemeroteca.abc.es/nav/Navigate.exe/hemeroteca/madrid/abc/1904/04/14/001.html here]</ref> Today out of use and entirely forgotten.
===provincias vascas===
In Spanish literally ''Basque provinces''. The term entered circulation in the 19th century, though in terms of press usage until the Civil War it trailed far behind “provincias vascongadas” or “país vasco”.<ref>in ''ABC'' the usage ratio between “provincias vascas” and “provincias vascongadas” was 1:4.7 in the 1910s, 1:3.2 in the 1920s and 1:2.2 in the 1930s (until July 1, 1936), compare search engine availeble [http://hemeroteca.abc.es/avanzada.stm here]</ref> The term put slightly more emphasis on Basque character of the area than “provincias vascongadas” did.<ref>Rubio Pobes 2003, p. 45</ref> Its usage by no means implied support for Basque cause either politically or otherwise (though it might have). Geographical application of the term was ambiguous. Most commonly it referred to Álava, Biscay and Gipuzkoa, though it might have referred also to Navarre<ref>apart from nationalist discourse at times also in scholarly works, compare Santiago de Pablo Contreras, ''El Estatuto vasco y la cuestión foral en Navarra durante la II República'', [in:] ''Gerónimo de Uztariz'' 2 (1988), pp. 42-48</ref> and (rarely) even to 3 French provinces;<ref>Rubio Pobes 2003, pp. 45-6</ref> in such cases it usually focused on ethnic question. Today it is used sometimes (rather occasionally) to denote Álava, Biscay and Gipuzkoa. It was not capitalized (usage of “Provincias Vascas” is rather exceptional).
===provincias vascongadas===
also '''Provincias Vascongadas, provincias Vascongadas, provincias bascongadas, provincias Bascongadas, Provincias Bascongadas, provincias baskongadas'''. In Spanish literally ''Basque-speaking provinces''. The term entered circulation in the 17th century<ref>first noted in the 1624 work of Juan de Grijalva, ''Cróníca de la Orden de n. p. s. Agustín en las provincias de la Nueva España''</ref> and remained in use until the first half of the 20th century, though since the late 19th century with decreasing unofficial usage. Until the 1930s it was the official administrative name of the region (in this usage capitalized).<ref>''Guía Oficial de España'' 1911, p. 611, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0001038237&page=599 here]</ref> Until the early 20th century it was also the most common, rather neutral way of naming the area in question; in the 1920s it started to give precedence to “País Vasco”.<ref>in ''ABC'' the usage ratio between “País Vasco” and “Provincias Vascongadas” was 1:1.4 in the 1910s (67 vs 94), 1.4:1 in the 1920s (295 vs 211) and 2.8:1 in the 1930s (until July 1, 1936, 635 vs 226), compare [http://hemeroteca.abc.es/avanzada.stm here]</ref> Though the name technically pointed to distinct linguistic character of the area, the component was later subject to lexicalization and ceased to stand out.<ref>compare definitions offered by ''Diccionario de la lengua castellana'', 3rd edition (Madrid 1781) and 6th edition (Madrid 1822)</ref> Usage of the term did not imply the intention to underline a separate, Basque ethnic character of the provinces.<ref>Rubio Pobes 2003, p. 45</ref> The term was generally applied to Álava, Biscay and Gipuzkoa,<ref>compare e.g. ''Mercurio histórico y político'' May 1766, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0012194633&page=76 here] or ''El Sol'' 01.04.20, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000232461&page=5 here]</ref> exceptionally also to Navarre.<ref>see José Canga Argüelles, ''Diccionario de Hacienda'', Madrid 1834, pp. 461-464</ref> Today almost entirely out of circulation, used very sporadically and generally against a historical background.<ref>compare ''ABC'' 26.01.14, available [http://hemeroteca.abc.es/nav/Navigate.exe/hemeroteca/sevilla/abc.sevilla/2014/01/26/020.html here]</ref>
===Vascongadas===
also '''Bascongadas, bascongadas, Baskongadas''', in Spanish literally ''Basque-speaking [provinces, territory, area, country]''. Developed as an abbreviated form of “Provincias Vascongadas”, and not seldom used in official documents until the 1930s.<ref>''Guía oficial de España'' 1922, p. 847, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0001038237&page=847 here] </ref> In unofficial circulation “Vascongadas” along “Provincias Vascongadas” was the most common denomination until the late [[Restoration (Spain)|Restoration]] period, but gave way to “País Vasco” in the 1920s-1930s.<ref>e.g. in 1934 the ''ABC'' ratio between editorial usage (i.e. except commercials, official names etc.) of “Vascongadas” and “País Vasco” was ca 1:3, compare [http://hemeroteca.abc.es/avanzada.stm here]</ref> Though technically it pointed to Basque character of the area in question, the feature was entirely lexicalized and did not stand out. Fairly neutral in usage, deprived of ethnic, let alone national notions. A rather slight difference between “Vascongadas” and “Provincias Vascongadas” was that the former name did not acknowledge provinces, either in terms of their heterogeneity or in terms of their forming part of Spanish administrative structure; however, this technical lexical difference has usually not been exploited for political reasons. Geographically the term was applied to Álava, Biscay and Gipuzkoa, though sporadically it could have included also Navarre.<ref>e.g. ''Diccionario de Hacienda'' of Canga Argüelles (1834) claimed that "este nombre [Provincias Exentas] llevan las de Navarra, Vizcaya, Álava y Guipúzcoa, conocidas también con el de vascongadas"</ref> The term was almost eradicated – at least in territorial application – during [[Francoism]].<ref>though it was seldom used, see ''ABC'' 29.06.58, available [http://hemeroteca.abc.es/nav/Navigate.exe/hemeroteca/madrid/abc/1958/06/29/043.html here]</ref> Except sporadic cases and rather accidental usage in official documents<ref>compare ''BOE'' 252 (2012), available [http://www.boe.es/buscar/doc.php?id=BOE-A-2012-13026 here]; the usage appears to be actually an editorial negligence resulting form copy-pasting proper name of a company</ref> it was not revived afterwards, as most common denomination replaced by “País Vasco”. Currently out of circulation, except in historical discourse or in personal columns, sometimes consciously used to note nominal controversies.<ref>compare ''ABC'' 29.01.14, available [http://hemeroteca.abc.es/nav/Navigate.exe/hemeroteca/sevilla/abc.sevilla/2014/01/29/017.html here], or ''ABC'' 16.12.14, available [http://hemeroteca.abc.es/nav/Navigate.exe/hemeroteca/sevilla/abc.sevilla/2014/12/16/003.html here]</ref>
===Vasconia===
also '''vasconia, baskonia, Baskonia, Wasconia''', also plural '''Vasconiae, Vasconias''', and part of the etymology of ''[[Gascony]]''. In [[Latin language|Latin]] ''Basque Land''. The term emerged in Roman times and until medieval era it was occasionally used in Latin documents and maps, usually with ambiguous geographical rather than political denotation.<ref>Agirreazkuenaga 2011, 65-66, see also Koldo Larrañaga Elortza, ''De «wasco» a «Wasconia» y «Vascongadas». Disquisiciones sobre ciertos corrimientos onomásticos en la Alta Edad Media'', [in:] ''Entre Euskadi y Euskalherria, vicisitudes de un concepto'' (conference paper 1985)</ref> Rarely used in Spanish;<ref>the Spanish national hemeroteca quotes only 15 cases of usage in the 1840s, 11 in the 1850s, 12 in the 1860s</ref> when used in plural it referred to 2 parts (“ambas Vasconias”,<ref>''La Voz'' 20.08.24, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000798465&page=1 here]</ref> “dos Vasconias”<ref>''Revista de Archivos, Bibliotecas y Museos'' 1 (1897), p. 495, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000019631&page=15 here]</ref>): the Spanish and the French one. It enjoyed modest revival in the late 19th century,<ref>224 cases of usage in the 1870s, 68 in the 1880s, and 320 in the 1890s</ref> used generally against a cultural, historical and regional background; it appeared mostly in literary or scientific Vascólogist discourse. The term underlined commonality of Basque area but was deprived of political notions; it tended to put common history on the forefront. It lacked clear geographical meaning and was applied according to perceived territorial coverage of the Basque realm. Following demise in the early 20th century,<ref>e.g. in 1934 ''ABC'' used the term "Vasconia" around 10 times (except in official names or strictly historical usage), while “Pais Vasco” was used around 60 times</ref> “Vasconia” enjoyed some revival during Francoism; unlike politically-charged “país vasco” or “provincias vascas”, censorship tolerated it easily as a historical, semi-scientific reference. Following brief confusion among the nationalists in the mid-1960s,<ref>mostly thanks to Federico Krutwig, who put forward his idea of armed violence against the Spanish state in a 1963 work titled “Vasconia”, Fernández Sebastián, Fuentes Aragonés 2008, p. 875</ref> currently it is out of use except for historical discourse (or names of institutions, sporting associations etc.).

{{About||the 2013 film|Nordvest (film)}}
'''Nordvest''' ([[Literal translation|lit.]]: '''Northwest''', short form of '''[[Copenhagen]] North West''') or '''The North West Block''' is an area in [[Denmark]]'s [[Copenhagen Municipality|Copenhagen municipality.]] It is located in the southwestern part of the [[Bispebjerg]] district. Although there are no clear borders nor any official demarcation, it is broadly recognized as the area covered mostly by [[List of postal codes in Denmark|the Danish postal code]] ''2400 København NV'' (''NV'' being shorthand for ''Nordvest''),<ref name="dr">Radio broadcast [http://www.dr.dk/P1/Serier/20110131114755.htm 2400 NV], sent 2011-01-31 20:03 on [[DR (broadcaster)|DR P1]] in Danish</ref> although some areas lie outside this postal code. As of 2005, 44,177 people resided in the area.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.statistikbanken.dk/statbank5a/SelectVarVal/Define.asp?Maintable=PNR1 | title=PNR1: Befolkningen efter område (postnumre) (AFSLUTTET) | publisher=[[Statistics Denmark]] | trans-title=Population by area (postal codes) (COMPLETED) | language=Danish}}</ref>
== History == A large area of the current Nordvest previously formed part of the Brønshøj-[[Rødovre Municipality|Rødovre]] municipality, which consisted mostly of low-density housing and small businesses.<ref name="dr" /><ref name="lokh">{{cite web | url=http://www.agendaforening-nordvest.dk/tekster/Nr%202%20R4_%2009%2005%2021%20Kvartervand%20Rentemestervej%20An%E2%80%A6.pdf | title=Kvartervandring i Nordvestkvarteret] af Lokalhistorisk Arkiv Bispebjerg-Nordvest | language=Danish | trans-title=Area hike in ''Nordvest'' by the Bispebjerg-Nordvest local historic archives}}</ref> In the early 20th century, the Copenhagen municipality annexed the area from the Brønshøj-Rødovre municipality in order to construct a "socially democratic ideal where one can live from cradle to grave without moving more than a few blocks."<ref name="dr" /> Consequently, in the following years a large number of [[social housing]] units and [[homeless shelter]]s were constructed and soon populated by evicted residents from central Copenhagen (which was undergoing a housing "sanitization" during this time). Along with the construction of social housing, the area's readily available workforce also built small and large industrial complexes in the unused areas between the houses. This gave rise to the construction of different kinds of housing, such as the ''typografernes hus'' (lit.: ''[[typographer]]'s housing''), a type of housing in which residents live in the above-ground area and old, functional printing presses are housed in the basement.<ref name="dr" />
Throughout the 1980s, the ''Nordvest'' was increasingly characterized as an area for apartments, which were relatively inexpensive compared to those in the surrounding areas of Copenhagen. In 1980, the area was designated by the community psychiatric authorities to house people with mental health diagnoses in the community. However, soon thereafter there was a spike in vandalism and assaults.<ref name="dr" /> In 1993, the Ministry of Housing, the [[Ministry of Social Affairs (Denmark)|Ministry of Social Affairs]], and the Copenhagen municipality agreed on a "holistic effort in the Nordvest" to improve the situation.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.kvarterloeft.dk/publikationer/rapporter/rapp_1.htm | title=Kvarterløft - Rumlig modernisering of social rummelighed, rapport af Axel R. Kristiansen og Jørgen Bang, Roskilde Universitets Center | dead-url=usurped | language=Danish | trans-title=Area improvements - open minded modernization and social tolerance, report by Axel R. Kristiansen and Jørgen Bangm, Roskilde University}}</ref> This would later serve as a model and precursor for later area improvement projects elsewhere in Denmark.
By 2013, the area had experienced a partial urban regeneration, characterized by an ethnically diverse population and a wide range of small businesses, while the industrial complexes were largely renovated and converted to modern housing. A film on the subject was directed by Michael Noer.<ref name="dr" />
== Characteristics and attractions == The area is bordered (from the north, clockwise) by the remaining part of [[Bispebjerg]], the districts [[Østerbro]] and [[Nørrebro]], the municipality of [[Frederiksberg]], and the districts [[Vanløse]] and [[Brønshøj-Husum]]. The major roads Tagensvej, Frederiksborgvej, Tuborgvej/Tomsgårdsvej/Hjulgårdsvej, Borups Allé, and Hillerødgade all cut through ''Nordvest''.
Two large green areas can be found in the area: [[Utterslev Mose]] is the northwest border of the area, and the ''Bispebjerg Kirkegård'' cemetery is near the center. Smaller green areas include the ''Emaljehaven'' (lit.: the Enamel Garden), a renovated green area that previously housed a large metal workshop,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.arkark.dk/building.aspx?buildingid=13067|title= Arkark.dk: Emaljehaven}}</ref> ''Rødkilde park'' (lit.: The Red Source park), which hosts the Rødkilde Nature Playground<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.gogreencopenhagen.dk/gogreencopenhagen/steder/opleve/det-er-for-boern/naturlegepladsen-i-roedkildeparken/?lang=en |title=Go Green Copenhagen: Rødkilde Nature Playground}}</ref> and the ''Nordvestparken'' (lit.: the North West park), constructed in 2009, which won the Danish Light Award in 2010.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.lemming-eriksson.dk/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=138&Itemid=187 |title=Lemming-Eriksson: Nordvestparken| language=Danish|trans-title=Lemming-Eriksson: The North West park}}</ref>
The earlier social housing and industrial buildings have undergone a transformation: while many of the old buildings are still standing, they have been repurposed. Most of the old buildings have not been modernized, and only some have been partially modernized.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://2400nv.com/#/nordvest/ | title=2400 NV: Lyt til stedets stemmer | language=Danish | trans-title=2400 NV: Listen to the areas voices}}</ref> With the relocation of much of the industry to less populated areas, the old industrial complexes provide an opportunity for modern housing and activities. One such example of the modernization of the old ''[[Ungdomshuset]]'' area was the creation of a large cultural creativity space, ''Boljefabrikken'' (lit. the candy factory), housed in an old smithy and plumbing factory. The area's rugged image persists, and because of this it has acquired the nicknames ''Nordværst'' (''North Worst'') and ''Nordlædervest'' (''North Leather Vest'').<ref name="guld">{{cite web | first1=Per | last1=Theimann | url=http://politiken.dk/tjek/penge/dinepenge/ECE1962638/det-rette-postnummer-er-guld-vaerd | title=Det rette postnummer er guld værd | publisher=[[Politiken]] | date=2013-05-04 | language=Danish | trans-title=The right postal code is worth a lot}}</ref> As a result, housing costs are comparatively lower than other areas of Copenhagen; in the neighboring district of Østerbro and the neighboring municipality of Frederiksberg, housing prices are on average 50% higher than in Nordvest.<ref name="guld" /> Crime rates, however, are the same as in most of urban Copenhagen.<ref name="guld" />
Even though the area is formally a part of the district ''Bispebjerg'', the ''Nordvest'' is often associated with the district [[Nørrebro]],<ref>{{cite web | url=http://subsite.kk.dk/eDoc/%C3%98konomiudvalget/16-01-2001%2015.00/Dagsorden/23-05-2003%2013.59.24/9311EB5389045857C1256D2F0041DCF5.htm | title=Dagsorden for ordinært mode tirsdag den 16. januar 2001 i Københavns kommunes økonomiudvalg | trans-title=Agenda for ordinary meeting in Copenhagen municipality's fiscal board on 2001-01-16 | language=Danish}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.folkesundhed.kk.dk/TilKoebenhavnere/MotionOgKost/Motionslisten/N%C3%B8rrebro%20og%20Nordvest.aspx | title=Folkesundhed i Norrebro og Nordvest | language=Danish | trans-title=Public health in Norrebro and Nordvest}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=https://subsite.kk.dk/sitecore/content/Subsites/Forebyggelsescentrene/SubsiteFrontpage/Motion/Motionslisten/Norrebro.aspx | title=Forebyggelsescentrene Nørrebro-Nordvest | trans-title=Prevention centres in Nørrebro and Nordvest | language=Danish}}</ref> and Copenhagen municipality is actively creating a more pervasive integration of ''Nordvest'' and Nørrebro.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://subsite.kk.dk/~/media/63D4D69CE9EB419F876F7A89B774A5B4.ashx | title=Udviklingsplan Nørrebro (TMF 129) af Københavns Kommune | trans-title=Development plan for Norrebro (TMF 129) by Copenhagen municipality | language=Danish}}</ref>
== Notable people == * [[Jan Sonnergaard]] – author
== See also == {{Commons category|Nordvest|position=left}}
== References == {{Reflist}}

revision.comment: Fix [[:Category:Pages using deprecated image syntax]]; [[WP:GenFixes]] on, using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
{{primary sources|date=September 2012}}
{{Infobox organization |name = |logo = Okapi Conservation Project Logo.jpg |logo_size = 200px |type = [[Non-profit Organization]] |founded_date = 1987 |founder = John Lukas |location = |location_country = [[Democratic Republic of Congo]] |area_served = [[Ituri Forest]] |origins = | key_people = |focus = [[Okapi]] Conservation |method = |revenue = |num_volunteers = |owner = |Non-profit_slogan = |homepage = [http://www.okapiconservation.org okapiconservation.org/] |dissolved = |footnotes = }}
The '''Okapi Conservation Project''' ('''OCP''') was founded in 1987 for the protection of the [[okapi]]s (''Okapia johnstoni'') and their [[habitat]]. [[Okapi]]s are only found in the [[Democratic Republic of Congo]]<ref name="wcn">{{cite web |url = http://wildlifeconservationnetwork.org/wildlife/okapi2.html#conservationist |title = Okapi Conservation Project |publisher = Wildlife Conservation Network}}</ref> and are seen as the major flagship species of the [[Ituri Forest]].<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.africanconservation.org/content/view/79/409/ |title = Okapi Conservation Project |publisher = African Conservation Foundation}}</ref> The OCP has about one hundred staff members and one hundred and ten government rangers under the direction of the Institute in Congo for the Conservation of Nature. The Okapi Conservation Project is partnered with the [[Wildlife Conservation Network]].<ref>{{cite web |url = http://wildlifeconservationnetwork.org/wildlife/okapi.html |title = Okapi Conservation Project |publisher = [[Wildlife Conservation Network]]}}</ref> OCP's founder John Lukas is also a founding member of the Wildlife Conservation Network.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://wildlifeconservationnetwork.org/about/team2.html#board |title =WCN Board of Directors |publisher = [[Wildlife Conservation Network]]}}</ref> In 1992 the project helped create the [[Okapi Wildlife Reserve]], encompassing 13,700 square kilometers of the [[Ituri Forest]], which was designated as a [[United Nations]] [[World Heritage Site]] in 1996.<ref name="wcn"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/718 |author=UNESCO World Heritage Centre |date=1992–2017 |title=Okapi Wildlife Reserve |access-date=2017-10-27}}</ref>
==2012 attack== In June 2012 the headquarters for the Okapi Wildlife Reserve was taken over by poachers, intent on retaliating against the staff who had been stopping their elephant poaching and mining operations. Six guards and other staff as well as 14 [[okapi]]s were killed in the incident. The local village was looted, women were raped and the conservation center was burned down.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.huffingtonpost.com/jeffrey-flocken/okapi-wildlife-reserve-attack_b_1634403.html |title = Tragic Losses in the Heart of Darkness |publisher = Huffington Post}}</ref>
==Programs==
===Okapi Wildlife Reserve=== The [[Okapi Wildlife Reserve]] – an area 13,700 square kilometers, about one-fifth of the [[Ituri Forest]] – was created with the help of the Okapi Wildlife Project in 1992. The project continues to support the reserve by training and equipping wildlife guards and by providing assistance to improve the lives of neighboring communities.<ref name="wcn"/> The Okapi Wildlife Reserve was added to the list of [[World Heritage Site]]s in 1996, and since 1997 it has been listed as a World Heritage Site in danger.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.marketwatch.com/story/poachers-attack-okapi-wildlife-reserve-2012-06-25 |title = Poachers Attack Okapi Wildlife Reserve |publisher = Wall Street Journal Market Watch}}</ref>
===Agro-forestry=== The program provides farmers with resources to make their farmland more productive, thus decreasing farmers' need for forest land.<ref name="wcn"/> The program also works to reforest unused areas.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://houstonzooblogs.org/wildconservation/2010/05/the-okapi-conservation-project/ |title = The Okapi Conservation Project |publisher = [[Houston Zoo]]}}</ref>
===Conservation education and community assistance=== OCP offers an education team that travels throughout the Okapi Wildlife Reserve, providing workshops, lectures, and presentations on the importance of biodiversity conservation and sustainable management of forest resources. The team also distributes education materials to all of the twenty-three schools in the Okapi Wildlife Reserve. They also assist in school construction.<ref name="wcn"/>
===Other projects=== Other projects include finding alternatives to hunting [[bush meat]], such as raising [[tilapia]] and [[cane rat]]s. Another activity is providing air surveillance and wildlife guard response to stop illegal activities in the reserve.<ref name="wcn"/>
==See also== {{Portal|Sustainable development|Environment|Ecology}} * [[Wildlife Conservation Network]] * [[Conservation movement]] * [[Environmental movement]] * [[Natural environment]] * [[Sustainability]]
==References== {{Reflist|colwidth=30em}}
==External links== {{Commons|Okapia johnstoni}} {{wikispecies|Okapia johnstoni}} * [http://www.okapiconservation.org okapiconservation.org/ Okapi Conservation Project Website] * [http://wildnet.org/ wildnet.org], [[Wildlife Conservation]] Network Website
{{DEFAULTSORT:Okapi Conservation Project}} [[Category:Organizations established in 1987]] [[Category:International environmental organizations]] [[Category:Endangered species]] [[Category:Wildlife conservation organizations]] [[Category:Conservation projects]]

[[File:Moby Dick Kamouraska.jpg|thumb|Climber on an overhang (''Moby Dick'' route, [[climbing grade|5.11b]], [[Kamouraska, Quebec|Kamouraska]], Canada)]] [[File:Dachzone Westliche Zinne.jpg|thumb|The large roof of the [[Western Zinne]] forms an overhang of 40 metres]]
An '''overhang''' is a [[rock face]] or artificial [[climbing wall]] with a slope of more than 90°, i.e. it slopes beyond the [[Vertical direction|vertical]]. Particularly severe overhangs that reach, or nearly reach, the [[horizontal plane|horizontal]], are referred to as a '''roof'''.<ref>{{citation/core|Surname1=Gabi Flecken|Title=Klettern in der Halle |Publisher=Meyer & Meyer|Year=2008|At=pp. 120|ISBN=9783898992961|Date= 2008|language=German|URL=https://books.google.com/books?id=Rvm7IFJx5_0C&pg=PT120&dq=|Format= Google Books|AccessDate=20 September 2009}}</ref>
In [[climbing]], overhangs and especially roofs place special demands both in terms of technique and equipment as well as the constitution of the sportsman or sportswoman.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.kletter-bergsport.de/html/lexikon-klettern.html |title=Kletter - Lexikon |access-date=20 September 2009}} </ref> With increasing steepness the loading on arm and hand muscles increases, because the feet can support less and less of the body weight. Rest points where the muscles can be relaxed, especially [[no-hands rest]]s, are rarely found in overhangs. Climbing techniques to tackle overhangs include placing the [[Center of mass|body's centre of mass]] as close as possible to the rock and striving for the highest possible body tension (German: ''Körperspannung'').<ref>{{citation/core|Surname1=Udo Neumann|Title=Lizenz zum Klettern 2.0 |Publisher=Udini Verlag|PublicationPlace=Köln|Year=2001|At=pp. 36|ISBN=3-9804809-0-9|Date= 2001|language=German}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.t5e.de/Workshops/Klettertechnik/Klettertechnik02.php |title=Klettertechnik - Überhänge |access-date=20 September 2009}} </ref> Many climbing techniques such as the [[foothook]] are almost exclusively used in overhangs and roofs.<ref> {{citation/core|Surname1=Marietta Uhden|Periodical=[[Climb!]]|Title=Mit Schwung |Volume=6|Issue=08|Year=2008|At=pp. 58|Date= 2008|language=German|URL=http://www.climb.de/_downloads/zeitschriftenartikel/cl_akt_dow_0608_technik.pdf|AccessDate=20 September 2009}} </ref> For a long time in [[Alpine climbing]], roofs were almost always tacked using [[aid climbing|climbing aids]]. By contrast, in modern [[sport climbing]], severely overhanging terrain is no longer a rarity, because [[indoor climbing|climbing halls]] frequently include overhangs and roofs.
A well-known natural example of severely overhanging terrain is the rook in the north face of the [[Drei Zinnen|Western Zinne]], whose upper end is about 40 metres horizontally from the foot of the rock face. Severe [[climbing route]]s that feature overhangs and roofs include [[Separate Reality (climbing route)|Separate Reality]] in the USA and [[La Rambla (climb)|La Rambla]] in Spain.
== See also == * [[Rock shelter]] * [[Abri]] * [[Mount Thor]], the world's highest overhang
== References == <references />
[[Category:Geomorphology]] [[Category:Climbing]]

revision.text:
'''Sredorek''' ({{lang-mk|Средорек}}) is a historical and geographical region in northeastern [[Republic of Macedonia]]. It includes settlements in the [[Pčinja river]] valley, parts of the mountainous regions of [[Kozjak (Kumanovo)|Kozjak]] (Kozjačija), [[German (mountain)|German]] and [[Rujen (mountain)|Rujen]], which are today located within the [[Municipality of Staro Nagoričane]]. The region is predominantly inhabited by [[ethnic Macedonians]] and ethnic [[Serbs]] (see [[Serbs in the Republic of Macedonia]]), adherents of [[Eastern Orthodoxy]]. In the Middle Ages, the region was part of the ''[[župe]]'' (counties) of [[Žegligovo (župa)|Žegligovo]] and [[Preševo (župa)|Preševo]].
Notable monuments in the region include the [[Church of St. George, Staro Nagoričane|Church of St. George]],
==Geography== The region includes settlements in the [[Pčinja river]] valley, parts of the mountainous regions of [[Kozjak (Kumanovo)|Kozjak]] (Kozjačija), [[German (mountain)|German]], [[Rujen (mountain)|Rujen]], which are today located within the [[Municipality of Staro Nagoričane]]; roughly from Pčinja and the lower course of the Kriva Reka.<ref name="Зечевић">{{cite book|author=др Слободан Зечевић|title=Гласник Етнографског музеја у Београду књ. 36: Bulletin du Musée Ethnographique de Belgrade|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Yj-lBQAAQBAJ&pg=PA16|publisher=Etnografski muzej u Beogradu|pages=16–|id=GGKEY:L58360RG0XK|quote=Средорек (између Пчиње и доњег тока Криве реке)}}</ref> The region borders [[Serbia]] to the north, and the historical and geographical regions of [[Slavište]] and [[Stracin]].
==Settlements== {{expand list|date=March 2015}} [[File:Staro Nagoričane Municipality.svg|thumb|Map of the [[Municipality of Staro Nagoričane]] (in Macedonian).]] *[[Staro Nagoričane]], Kozjak region *[[Ruǵince]], Pčinja valley *[[Dejlovce]], German region *[[Vračevce]], Kozjak region *[[Malotino]], Rujen region *[[Stepance]], Kozjak and German region *[[Strezovce, Staro Nagoričane|Strezovce]], Pčinja valley *[[Strnovac]], Rujen region *[[Cvilance]], Pčinja valley *[[Čelopek, Staro Nagoričane|Čelopek]], Pčinja valley *[[Ramno, Staro Nagoričane|Ramno]], Kozjak and German region *[[Puzajka]], Rujen region *[[Pelince]], Pčinja valley *[[Osiče]], German region *Orah, Pčinja valley *[[Oblavce]], Pčinja valley *[[Nikuljane]], mountainous region *[[Mlado Nagoričane]], Pčinja valley *[[Makreš]], Pčinja valley *[[Miglence]], Rujen region *[[Kokino, Staro Nagoričane|Kokino]], Kozjak region *[[Koince]], Pčinja valley *[[Karlovce]], Kozjak region *[[Kanarevo]], Pčinja valley *[[Željuvino]], German region *[[Žegljane]], Kozjak region *[[Dragomance]], Pčinja valley *[[Dobrača, Staro Nagoričane|Dobrača]], Pčinja valley *[[Vragoturce]], Kozjak region *[[Vojnik, Staro Nagoričane|Vojnik]], Pčinja valley *[[Bukovljane]], Kozjak region *[[Breško]], German region *[[Bajlovce]], German region *[[Arbanaško, Staro Nagoričane|Arbanaško]], Kozjak and German region *[[Aljince]], German region *[[Algunja]], mountainous
==History== In 1354, when Dejan had finished building the [[Arhiljevica]] Church of the Holy Mother of God, his [[Endowment (philosophy)|endowment]], he asked that some of the villages under his administration be granted to the church (as ''[[metochion]]'').<ref name=Blagojevic-2007-448>{{harvnb|Blagojević|2007|pp=448–449}}</ref> According to Stefan Dušan's [[charter]] to Arhiljevica dated 10 August 1354,<ref name=Blagojevic-2007-448/> ''sevastokrator'' Dejan, whom he called his ''brother'' ("брат царства ми севастократор Дејан"),<ref name=Mandic-161>{{harvnb|Mandić|1986|p=161}} {{quote|У повељи манастиру Архиљевици, издатој ав- густа 1355. године, Душан на три места каже: „Брат царства ми севастократор Дејан". Именица брат има вишеструко значење. Најодређеније је оно примарно: рођени брат.}}</ref> possessed a large province east of [[Skopska Crna Gora]]. It included the old ''[[župe]]'' (counties) of [[Žegligovo (župa)|Žegligovo]] and [[Preševo (župa)|Preševo]] (modern [[Kumanovo]] region with Sredorek, [[Kozjačija]] and the larger part of [[Pčinja District|Pčinja]]).<ref name=IdNRS1951-20>{{harvnb|Istorisko Društvo NR Srbije|1951|pp=20–21}} {{quote|према повељи манастиру богоро- дичимог ваведења у Архиљевици,50 држао као своју баштину пространу област иеточно од Скопске Црне Горе. Она је обухватала старе жупе Прешево и Жеглигово (данас кумановски крај са Средореком, Козјачијом...}}</ref> Among the granted villages, still existing today in Sredorek, were: [[Ruǵince]], [[Dejlovce]] and [[Vračevce]].
Serbian geographer and sociologist [[Jovan Cvijić]] travelled and studied the lands, and included the region of Sredorek (chapter "Средорек, Страцин и Славиште").<ref name="Cvijić1906">{{cite book|author=Jovan Cvijić|title=Osnove za geografiju i geologiju Makedonije|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=N4owAQAAMAAJ|year=1906|publisher=Štampano u državnoj štampariji Kraljevine Srbije}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|title=Narodna privreda u prisajedinjenim oblastima: izveštaji komisija ministrstva narodne privede|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=FYQ-AQAAMAAJ|year=1914|publisher=Izd. ministarstva narodne privrede}}</ref> [[Jovan Hadži-Vasiljević]] also travelled and studied the lands.
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Geography of the Republic of Macedonia]] [[Category:Staro Nagoričane Municipality]]

'''95-6''' [[Sasebo, Nagasaki|Sasebo]] '''96''' [[Kumamoto]] '''97''' [[Ōita, Ōita|Ōita]] '''98-8 or 98-9''' [[Naha]] '''98-1 or 98-5''' [[Miyazaki, Miyazaki|Miyazaki]] '''99''' [[Kagoshima]] Geographic numbers are nine digits long, including the area code, but not including the leading zero. Consequently, densely populated areas have shorter area codes, while less populated areas have longer area codes. For example: * '''6''' xxxx xxxx (Osaka) * '''75''' xxx xxxx (Kyoto) * '''74-2''' xx xxxx (Nara) * '''49-92''' x xxxx (Niijima island, Tokyo pref.) * '''82-486''' xxxx (Takano, Hiroshima pref.) Area codes increase from north to south; [[Sapporo, Hokkaidō|Sapporo]] in [[Hokkaidō]] (the northernmost prefecture) has '''11''', and [[Setouchi, Kagoshima|Setouchi]]'s '''99-73''' is far to the south in Kagoshima. When the telephone system was devised, Okinawa was still under [[Occupied Japan|U.S. occupation]], so when it was returned to Japan in 1972, its telephone numbers were squeezed between Miyazaki (98x) and Kagoshima (99x) and begin with 988, 989, and 980. During the 1990s, when plans were being drawn up to amalgamate mid-sized cities and towns into larger municipalities, telephone numbering systems were merged in advance. For example, *'''7442''' x xxxx Kashihara (Nara prefecture) *'''7444''' x xxxx Sakurai *'''74452''' xxxx Takatori *'''74454''' xxxx Asuka etc. became: * '''744''' 2x xxxx Kashihara * '''744''' 4x xxxx Sakurai * '''744''' 52 xxxx Takatori * '''744''' 54 xxxx Asuka etc. Many of these towns have in fact refused to merge, leaving callers with more digits to dial when making local calls. This is partially balanced by not having to dial an area code for the neighboring city. ==Area code as local brand naming== [[File:028Market.jpg|thumb|[[Flea Market]] event named "028 Market" held on the Union St. in Utsunomiya. This event is held about once in a half year.]] After entering the 2010s, local products and events have begun using names which come from the area code. 0465net ([[Odawara]], Kanagawa)
0428 T-shirt ([[Ome, Tokyo]])
028 Market ([[Utsunomiya]], Tochigi)
028 Machinaka (Inner-City) [[Wi-Fi]] (Utsunomiya, Tochigi)
Bar 053 ([[Hamamatsu]], Shizuoka) ==See also== * [[List of dialing codes in Japan]] * [[Communications in Japan#Telephone services|Communications in Japan § Telephone services]] * [[List of telephone operating companies#Japan|List of telephone operating companies § Japan]] * [[Telephone numbering plan]] == External links == * [http://www.jnto.go.jp/eng/arrange/essential/telephone.html Telephone information page] of the [[Japan National Tourist Organization]] (JNTO) ==References== {{Reflist}} *[http://www.itu.int/oth/T020200006D/en ITU allocations list] {{Telephone numbers in Asia}} [[Category:Telephone numbers by country|Japan]] [[Category:Telephone numbers in Japan| ]]

{{About|the weather phenomenon||Tradewind (disambiguation){{!}}Tradewind}} [[File:Map prevailing winds on earth.png|right|thumb|300px|The [[westerlies]] (blue arrows) and trade winds (yellow and brown arrows)]]
The '''trade winds''' are the [[Prevailing winds|prevailing pattern]] of surface [[wind]]s from the east toward the west (easterly) found in the [[tropics]], within the lower portion of the [[Earth's atmosphere]], in the lower part of the [[troposphere]] near the Earth's [[equator]]. The trade winds blow predominantly from the northeast in the [[Northern Hemisphere]] and from the southeast in the [[Southern Hemisphere]], strengthening during the winter and when the [[Arctic oscillation]] is in its warm phase. Trade winds have been used by captains of [[sailing ship]]s to cross the world's oceans for centuries, and enabled colonial expansion into the Americas and trade routes to become established across the [[Atlantic ocean|Atlantic]] and [[Pacific ocean]]s.
In [[meteorology]], the trade winds act as the [[prevailing winds|steering flow]] for [[tropical storms]] that form over the Atlantic, Pacific, and southern [[Indian Ocean]]s and make landfall in North America, Southeast Asia, and Madagascar and eastern Africa, respectively. Trade winds also transport African dust westward across the [[Atlantic Ocean]] into the [[Caribbean Sea]], as well as portions of southeastern [[North America]]. Shallow [[cumulus cloud]]s are seen within trade wind regimes, and are capped from becoming taller by a trade wind inversion, which is caused by descending air aloft from within the [[subtropical ridge]]. The weaker the trade winds become, the more rainfall can be expected in the neighboring landmasses.
== History == [[Image:Spanish Galleon.jpg|thumb|right|200px|A Spanish galleon]] {{See also|Age of Discovery|Volta do Mar|Age of sail}} The term ''trade winds'' originally derives from the early fourteenth century late [[Middle English]] word "trade," meaning "path" or "track."<ref>{{cite book|author1=Carol G. Braham |author2=Enid Pearsons |author3=Deborah M. Posner |author4=Georgia S. Maas |author5=Richard Goodman |last-author-amp=yes |title=Random House Webster's College Dictionary|year=2001|publisher=[[Random House]]|isbn=0-375-42560-8|edition=second|page=1385}}</ref> The Portuguese recognized the importance of the trade winds (then the ''[[Volta do mar]]'', meaning in Portuguese "turn of the sea" but also "return from the sea") in navigation in both the north and south Atlantic ocean as early as the 15th century.<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=w47gOifvK6EC&pg=PA38|title=Years of This Land - A Geographical History of the United States|author=Hermann R. Muelder|page=38|publisher=Read Books|year=2007|isbn=978-1-4067-7740-6}}</ref> From West Africa, the Portuguese had to sail away from continental Africa, that is, to west and northwest. They could then turn northeast, to the area around the [[Azores]] islands, and finally east to mainland Europe. They also learned that to reach South Africa, they needed to go far out in the ocean, head for Brazil, and around 30°S go east again. Following the African coast southbound means upwind in the Southern hemisphere. In the Pacific ocean, the full wind circulation, which included both the trade wind easterlies and higher-latitude [[Westerlies]], was unknown to Europeans until [[Andres de Urdaneta]]'s voyage in 1565.<ref name="pg18">{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=0Z26YL407SkC&pg=PA152|author=Derek Hayes|title=Historical atlas of the North Pacific Ocean: maps of discovery and scientific exploration, 1500–2000|page=18|publisher=Douglas & McIntyre|year=2001|isbn=978-1-55054-865-5}}</ref>
The captain of a sailing ship seeks a course along which the winds can be expected to blow in the direction of travel.<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=V0wAAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA19|title=A text-book of commercial geography|author=Cyrus Cornelius Adams|page=19|publisher=D. Appleton and company|year=1904}}</ref> During the [[Age of Sail]], the pattern of [[prevailing winds]] made various points of the globe easy or difficult to access, and therefore had a direct effect on European empire-building and thus on modern political geography. For example, [[Manila galleon]]s could not sail into the wind at all.<ref name="pg18"/>
[[File:Edmond Halley's map of the trade winds, 1686.jpg|thumb|275px|[[Edmond Halley]]'s map of the trade winds, 1686]] By the 18th century, the importance of the trade winds to England's merchant fleet for crossing the Atlantic Ocean had led both the general public and etymologists to identify the name with a later meaning of "trade": "(foreign) commerce".<ref>{{cite book|title=Oxford English Dictionary|edition=2|page=225}}</ref> Between 1847 and 1849, [[Matthew Fontaine Maury]] collected enough information to create wind and current charts for the world's oceans.<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=0Z26YL407SkC&pg=PA152|author=Derek Hayes|title=Historical atlas of the North Pacific Ocean: maps of discovery and scientific exploration, 1500–2000|page=152|publisher=Douglas & McIntyre|year=2001|isbn=978-1-55054-865-5}}</ref>
== Cause == [[File:Earth Global Circulation.svg|right|thumb|400px|3D map showing [[Hadley cell]]s in relationship to trade winds on the surface.]] {{See also|Air mass|Hadley cell|Humidity|Intertropical Convergence Zone|Monsoon|Monsoon trough|Near-equatorial trough|Prevailing winds}} As part of the [[Hadley cell]], surface air flows toward the equator while the flow aloft is towards the [[geographic pole|poles]]. A [[low-pressure area]] of calm, light variable winds near the equator is known as the [[doldrums]],<ref name="dold"/> near-equatorial trough,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://amsglossary.allenpress.com/glossary/search?p=1&query=doldrums&submit=Search|title=Doldrums|author=Glossary of Meteorology|publisher=[[American Meteorological Society]]|date=June 2000|accessdate=2009-11-09|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090925044123/http://amsglossary.allenpress.com/glossary/search?p=1&query=doldrums&submit=Search|archivedate=2009-09-25|df=}}</ref> intertropical front, or the [[Intertropical Convergence Zone]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://amsglossary.allenpress.com/glossary/search?p=1&query=intertropical+convergence+zone&submit=Search|title=Intertropical Convergence Zone|author=Glossary of Meteorology|publisher=[[American Meteorological Society]]|date=June 2000|accessdate=2009-11-09|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090602015342/http://amsglossary.allenpress.com/glossary/search?p=1&query=intertropical%2Bconvergence%2Bzone&submit=Search|archivedate=2009-06-02|df=}}</ref> When located within a [[monsoon]] region, this zone of low pressure and wind convergence is also known as the [[monsoon trough]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://amsglossary.allenpress.com/glossary/search?p=1&query=monsoon+trough&submit=Search|title=Monsoon Trough|author=Glossary of Meteorology|publisher=[[American Meteorological Society]]|date=June 2000|accessdate=2009-11-09|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090617192300/http://amsglossary.allenpress.com/glossary/search?p=1&query=monsoon+trough&submit=Search|archivedate=2009-06-17|df=}}</ref> Around 30° in both hemispheres, air begins to descend toward the surface in subtropical high-pressure belts known as [[subtropical ridge]]s. The subsident (sinking) air is relatively dry because as it descends, the temperature increases, but the absolute humidity remains constant, which lowers the relative humidity of the air mass. This warm, dry air is known as a superior air mass and normally resides above a maritime tropical (warm and moist) air mass. An increase of temperature with height is known as a temperature inversion. When it occurs within a trade wind regime, it is known as a trade wind inversion.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://amsglossary.allenpress.com/glossary/search?p=1&query=superior+air&submit=Search|title=Superior air|author=Glossary of Meteorology|date=June 2000|publisher=[[American Meteorological Society]]|accessdate=2009-10-28|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110606104219/http://amsglossary.allenpress.com/glossary/search?p=1&query=superior+air&submit=Search|archivedate=2011-06-06|df=}}</ref>
The surface air that flows from these subtropical high-pressure belts toward the Equator is deflected toward the west in both hemispheres by the [[Coriolis effect]].<ref>{{cite web |author=Glossary of Meteorology |title=trade winds |work=Glossary of Meteorology |publisher=American Meteorological Society |year=2009 |accessdate=2008-09-08 |url=http://amsglossary.allenpress.com/glossary/search?id=trade-winds1 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081211050708/http://amsglossary.allenpress.com/glossary/search?id=trade-winds1 |archivedate=2008-12-11 |df= }}</ref> These winds blow predominantly from the northeast in the [[Northern Hemisphere]] and from the southeast in the [[Southern Hemisphere]].<ref name="Ralph">{{cite book|author1=Ralph Stockman Tarr|author2=Frank Morton McMurry|author3=Almon Ernest Parkins|title=Advanced geography|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=OLMXAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA246|year=1909|publisher=State Printing|page=246}}</ref> Because winds are named for the direction from which the wind is blowing,<ref name="HOWTOREAD">{{cite web|author=JetStream|year=2008|url=http://www.srh.weather.gov/srh/jetstream/synoptic/wxmaps.htm|title=How to read weather maps|publisher=[[National Weather Service]]|accessdate=2007-05-16|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/68bsDeVx8?url=http://www.srh.weather.gov/srh/jetstream/synoptic/wxmaps.htm|archivedate=2012-06-22|df=}}</ref> these winds are called the northeasterly trade winds in the Northern Hemisphere and the southeasterly trade winds in the Southern Hemisphere. The trade winds of both hemispheres meet at the doldrums.<ref name="dold">{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=u-EMrG4bYJkC&pg=PA110|title=Introduction to Meteorology|author=Sverre Petterssen|page=110|publisher=Mcgraw-Hill Book Company, Inc.|year=1941|isbn=978-1-4437-2300-8}}</ref>
As they blow across tropical regions, air masses heat up over lower latitudes due to more direct sunlight. Those that develop over land (continental) are drier and hotter than those that develop over oceans (maritime), and travel northward on the western periphery of the subtropical ridge.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://amsglossary.allenpress.com/glossary/search?p=1&query=tropical+air&submit=Search|title=Tropical air|author=Glossary of Meteorology|date=June 2000|publisher=[[American Meteorological Society]]|accessdate=2009-10-28|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110606104145/http://amsglossary.allenpress.com/glossary/search?p=1&query=tropical+air&submit=Search|archivedate=2011-06-06|df=}}</ref> Maritime tropical air masses are sometimes referred to as trade air masses.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://amsglossary.allenpress.com/glossary/search?id=trade-air1|title=Trade air|author=Glossary of Meteorology|date=June 2000|publisher=[[American Meteorological Society]]|accessdate=2009-10-28|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110606104210/http://amsglossary.allenpress.com/glossary/search?id=trade-air1|archivedate=2011-06-06|df=}}</ref> The one region of the [[Earth]] which has an absence of trade winds is the north [[Indian ocean]].<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-mwbAsxpRr0C&pg=PA406|title=Encyclopedia of world climatology|author=John E. Oliver|page=128|isbn=978-1-4020-3264-6|publisher=Springer|year=2005}}</ref>
== Weather effects == Clouds which form above regions within trade wind regimes are typically composed of cumulus which extend no more than {{convert|4|km|ft}} in height, and are capped from being taller by the trade wind inversion.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.atmos.uiuc.edu/~rauber/researchRICO.htm|author=Bob Rauber|title=Research-The Rain in Cumulus over the Ocean Campaign|date=2009-05-22|accessdate=2009-11-08}}</ref> Trade winds originate more from the direction of the poles (northeast in the Northern Hemisphere, southeast in the Southern Hemisphere) during the cold season, and are stronger in the winter than the summer.<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=syqPSpliRCwC&pg=PA8|title=Tropical cyclones: climatology and impacts in the South Pacific|author=James P. Terry|page=8|isbn=978-0-387-71542-1|publisher=Springer|year=2007}}</ref> As an example, the windy season in the [[Guyana|Guianas]], which lie at low latitudes in [[South America]], occurs between January and April.<ref>{{cite journal|url=https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0025322704001045|title=The influence of the trade winds on the coastal development of the Guianas at various scale levels: a synthesis|author1=G. E. Pieter |author2=F. Augustinus |lastauthoramp=yes |doi=10.1016/j.margeo.2004.04.007|journal=Marine Geology|volume=208|issue=2–4|pages=145–151|bibcode=2004MGeol.208..145A|year=2004}}</ref> When the phase of the [[Arctic oscillation]] (AO) is warm, trade winds are stronger within the tropics. The cold phase of the AO leads to weaker trade winds.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://oceanworld.tamu.edu/resources/oceanography-book/oceananddrought.html|title=The Ocean's Influence on North American Drought |author=Robert R. Steward|publisher=[[Texas A&M University]]|year=2005}}</ref> When the trade winds are weaker, more extensive areas of rain fall upon landmasses within the tropics, such as [[Central America]].<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-mwbAsxpRr0C&pg=PA185|author=John E. Oliver|title=Encyclopedia of world climatology|page=185|isbn=978-1-4020-3264-6|publisher=Springer|year=2005}}</ref>
During mid-summer in the Northern Hemisphere (July), the westward-moving trade winds south of the northward-moving [[subtropical ridge]] expand northwestward from the [[Caribbean sea]] into southeastern North America (Florida and Gulf Coast). When dust from the [[Sahara]] moving around the southern periphery of the ridge travels over land, rainfall is suppressed and the sky changes from a blue to a white appearance which leads to an increase in red sunsets. Its presence negatively impacts [[air quality]] by adding to the count of airborne particulates.<ref name="pooraq">Science Daily (1999-07-14). [https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/1999/07/990714073433.htm African Dust Called A Major Factor Affecting Southeast U.S. Air Quality.] Retrieved on 2007-06-10.</ref> Although the Southeast USA has some of the cleanest air in North America, much of the African dust that reaches the United States affects Florida.<ref>Science Daily (2001-06-15). [https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2001/06/010615071508.htm Microbes And The Dust They Ride In On Pose Potential Health Risks.] Retrieved on 2007-06-10.</ref> Since 1970, dust outbreaks have worsened due to periods of drought in Africa. There is a large variability in the dust transport to the Caribbean and Florida from year to year.<ref>Usinfo.state.gov (2003). [http://www.gcrio.org/OnLnDoc/pdf/african_dust.pdf Study Says African Dust Affects Climate in U.S., Caribbean.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070620013708/http://www.gcrio.org/OnLnDoc/pdf/african_dust.pdf |date=2007-06-20 }} Retrieved on 2007-06-10.</ref> Dust events have been linked to a decline in the health of [[coral reef]]s across the Caribbean and Florida, primarily since the 1970s.<ref>[[U. S. Geological Survey]] (2006). [http://coastal.er.usgs.gov/african_dust/ Coral Mortality and African Dust.] Retrieved on 2007-06-10.</ref>
==See also== * [[Intertropical Convergence Zone]] * [[Volta do mar]] * [[Westerly wind burst]] * [[Winds in the Age of Sail]]
==References== {{Reflist|2}}
{{good article}}
[[Category:Climate patterns]] [[Category:Atmospheric dynamics]] [[Category:Wind]] [[Category:Age of Sail]]

{{Infobox mountain range | name=Tsiv-Gombori | other_name= | photo=Gombori in khirsa.JPG | photo_caption=View of Tsiv-Gombori mountains from Khirsa village | country={{flag|Georgia}} | region_type= | region=| region1=| region2= | parent=[[Greater Caucasus]] | border=| border1= | range_coordinates = {{coord|41|47|59|N|45|22|4|E|type:mountain|format=dms|display=inline,title}} | length_km=107| length_orientation= | width_mi= | width_orientation= | geology= | period= | orogeny= | highest=Mt. Tsivi | elevation_m=1990 | coordinates = | map=Georgia | map_caption= }} The '''Tsiv-Gombori''' ({{lang-ka|ცივ-გომბორის ქედი}}) or '''Gombori''' (გომბორი) is a [[mountain range]] in the [[Georgia (country)|Georgian]] section of [[Greater Caucasus]] mountains. It is located in the province of [[Kakheti]], eastern Georgia, and stretches to the distance of 107 km, with the highest mountain being at 1.991 m above sea level.
The Gombori range serves as a watershed, separating the [[Alazani]] and [[River Iori|Iori]] river valleys, thereby dividing Kakheti into two traditional regions: inner (Shida) and outer (Gare). The slopes of the range are traversed by several smaller river gorges. The Alazani passes through the mountain range affecting the overall climatic conditions in the region.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.samtrest.gov.ge/index.php?action=page&lang=eng&p_id=212 |title=Specific Zone ''Kakheti'' |accessdate=2011-05-26}}</ref> [[Mariamjvari Strict Nature Reserve]] is located in the southern side of the range. Both northern and southern slopes are home to [[Pine|pine forests]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://na-mo.web.officelive.com/mariamjvari.aspx |title=Nature Monuments. Mariamjvari |accessdate=2011-05-26}}</ref>
Tsiv-Gombori has been mentioned in media reports as a possible location for the US radar station for [[anti-ballistic missile]] systems which could provide surveillance of activities in Iran and up to the territory of India.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.vestikavkaza.ru/analytics/politika/36413.html |title=Дислокация радара – элемент военного присутствия США в Грузии |trans-title=Location of radar - element of presence of US in Georgia |publisher=Vestnik Kavkaza |author=Georgiy Kalatozishvili |date=2011-04-29 |accessdate=2011-05-26}}</ref>
==See also== {{commons category|Gombori}} * [[Caucasus Mountains]] * [[Telavi]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
